Question: Description
Answer: Hello MS Azure Team,

Actually we have received VM snapshot backup failure alerts for this host and upon checking this from our end, the waagent service is running fine on the VM also we have restarted the waagent service once and triggered the backup manually, but it got failed.

Further we checked in the Azure console overview option and observed the error displayed 'The last operation performed on this VM failed - VM still running'.

So we have tried reapply option but that is alos got failed later we set this VM in maintenance mode and tried stop/start the VM but VM stop operation also got failed.

We are suspecting some issues with this VM backend connectivty or hypervisor level. hence we are kindly requesting you to please have a look on this with high priority and help us to fix the issue.

Also please note that the same kind of errors displaying in the below listed VM's as well where we are getting VM backup failed alerts. So please have a look on these servers as well.

Question: Description
Answer: Hello Colleagues,

We noticed VM deployments are some times failed in Azure and from the OS logs we could see lot of waagent error right after the VM is starting up.

kiwi-image python[1071]: 2021/04/22 09:38:42.815088 WARNING ExtHandlerFetch failed from [http://168.63.129.16:32526/extensionArtifact]: [HTTP Failed] [400: Bad Request]

We use cloud-init to initialize the VM configuration and cloud-init use waagent to retrieve the system configuration.  So our analysis is that waagent failed to provide the system configuration and therefore VM deployment failed.

When we checked our previous deployments history, we could see that many deployments has failed in the last 90 days with this 'ExtHandler Fetch'. Some times immediate retry helps to deploy the VM but this issues is recurring more often.

Request you to take look at the earliest.

Thanks
Ajay

Answer: Hello Azure , 

Start Time:00:20:00 UTC on 24 March 2021 
End Time: 01:30:00 UTC on 24 March 2021 

Customer reported they have lost the connectivity to all HEC systems production and non-production systems. Issue fixed automaticaly after some time. No changes were made from our side. 

What we can see from OS side that all the servers unders this subscription had nfs errors. 

Some examples .

39a18cbc-4c2d-4274-9f88-36f950b91c25

2021-03-24T01:17:59.677386+00:00 hec45v103732 kernel: [3266149.340162] nfs: server vnsa79268 not responding, still trying

Question: Description
Answer: Hello,

We have experienced a auto reboot of Virtual Machine hec53v001634 on 02:45:00 UTC on 08 April 2021.

Can you please answer the following queries to finalize the RCA from our side?

1. Was it due to Host server(Hypervisor) failure where this VM residing?
2. If Yes, Host failed due to Hardware Failure?
3. If it is Hardware issue, Which exact part has failed and what about the redundancy for that faulty part?
4. If there were no HW issue, what else caused the VM auto reboot ?
5. How to mitigate such issues in future?(Applicable except for Hardware Failure).

Answer: Hello Azure team , 

we need assistance from Azure network team to analyse the below issue.

Question: Description
Answer: Hello ,



We have experienced a auto reboot of Virtual Machine hec44v005820 on 2021-04-08 17:37:54 (UTC).
The Azure monitoring and diagnostics systems identified that your VM hec44v005820 became unavailable at 2021-04-08 17:37:54 (UTC). 
During this time RDP and SSH connections to the VM, or requests to any other services running inside the VM, could have failed.

The Host Node where the VM was running encountered a hardware issue with the physical node where the virtual machine was hosted. 
This caused your VM to get rebooted.

Can you please answer the following queries to finalize the RCA from our side?

1. Was it due to Host server(Hypervisor) failure where this VM residing?
2. If Yes, Host failed due to Hardware Failure?
3. If it is Hardware issue, Which exact part has failed and what about the redundancy for that faulty part?
4. If there were no HW issue, what else caused the VM auto reboot ?
5. How to mitigate such issues in future?(Applicable except for Hardware Failure).

Answer: Unavailable : Root Cause Analysis (RCA) - IO Timeout
Root Cause
This unexpected occurrence was caused by an Azure initiated VM shutdown triggered by detection of temporary IO transaction timeouts between 
the physical host node where your VM was running, and the Azure Storage services where your Virtual Hard Disks (VHDs) reside.

Azure platform continuously monitors reads and writes (IO transactions) from your VMs to Azure Storage. 
If transactions do not complete successfully within 120 seconds (inclusive of retries), 
the connectivity is considered to be lost and a temporary VM shutdown is initiated to preserve data integrity and prevent corruption of your VM. 
After the platform detects that the storage service connectivity is restored, the VM is automatically restarted.

Remote disk disconnected (Unplanned)

We're sorry, your virtual machine is unavailable because of connectivity loss to the remote disk. We're working to reestablish disk connectivity. 
No additional action is required from you at this time.

Answer: Our customer has reported that they are unable to access any of their Application Gateway URLs from their on-premise environment. However they are reachable direct on the internet from other locations.  (FQDNs below).

Traffic is sourced from customer side (Post NAT) on 178.20.146.212 or 88.85.232.66.  Example PCAP snippet as follows:

2021-05-24 12:57:28.523480 port20 out 88.85.232.66.50150 - 51.144.120.80.443: syn 

Can you kindly be on standby to join a customer troubleshooting call to look at this as they would like to confirm that this traffic is actually arriving at the application gateway.  This has been raised a a priority 1 issue with us as this will impact customer go-live in their project.

We will forward the invite once available.

Maria from Microsoft mentioned that there was The physical host node where your VM is running had a networking stack update. This might result in a brief connectivity loss. which happened at 17:55 UTC 

we would like to check ,

- Why the writing to the local disk was very slow from 1:42 am ? was there already before 1:42 any issue occured in disk ?

- Why after reboot and redeploy the server worked for the replication 

Kindly provide a analysis of the health of the server during entire 01.04.2021 

thanks

Question: Description
Answer: Azure Team,

Vm server hec42v120487 was impacted due to 'Redeploying due to host failure (Unplanned)'

We request you a formal RCA about the issue reported with Host server.

Please contact Azure ACE Kevin F. to provide details about the RCA information requeted by SAP.


Can you please answer and include the following queries to finalize the RCA from our side?
1.Was it due to Host server(Hypervisor) failure where this VM residing?
2.If Yes, Host failed due to Hardware Failure?
3.If it is Hardware issue, Which exact part has failed and what about the redundancy for that faulty part?
4.If there were no HW issue, what else caused the VM auto reboot ?
5.How to mitigate such issues in future?(Applicable except for Hardware Failure).

Regards,
Jorge Munoz
